Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Mineral Removal from Biocoal Produced from Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) for Power Generation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project is for the mineral treatment technology for torrefied biomass. This technology enables the use of municipal solid waste (MSW) as a viable, and renewable fuel in coal power plant to commercialization. If successful, existing torrefaction technology can be deployed with the proposed mineral treatment to provide fuel generation at any site near existing waste infrastructure. With the addition of this technology, torrefaction technologies will be able to accept low-cost feedstock and produce cost competitive renewable fuels. This growth in such fuel companies could create many new jobs and the associated economic development. Because of the nature of MSW as an existing fuel source that is generated in all locations, there is potential to boost development around urban and rural areas through job creation, the utilization of renewable power generation, and reduction of society's waste streams.

The objectives of this Phase I research project are to remove or significantly reduce the mineral content within torrefied MSW. Torrefaction is a mild thermal treatment that transforms biomass to a fuel similar to coal, and is a proven technology. One major hurdle for torrefaction is the cost of the raw biomass materials. The use of wastes, such as MSW, can make the torrefied biomass (biocoal) cost competitive with fossil coal. MSW, however, contains a large fraction of minerals which cause slagging, fouling, and corrosion in fuel boilers. To overcome this barrier and realize the economic benefits from MSW utilization, Treamin Energy, Inc. has developed a method to remove nearly 100% of soluble and insoluble minerals quickly and inexpensively, and seeks to demonstrate Proof of Concept for the technology. With existing torrefaction and mineral treatment equipment, the process will be demonstrated from mineral, mass, and energy characterizations of the process steams, in addition to using measured process data in economic assessment tools for industrial potential.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electric utilities in the United States are under intense pressure to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases and toxic compounds from coal combustion without adversely affecting rate payers. The majority of the baseload power across the country is derived from pulverized coal boilers. Torrefied biomass (biocoal) is the only realistic drop-in fuel solution for a renewable, baseload substitute for coal.  Torrefaction is an old process that carbonizes biomass through mild heating in an environment without oxygen.  Recently,  developing technologies are being tested in quite a few locations to bring this process to a commercial scale. However, the main hindrance of biocoal is the high cost of the biomass feedstock.  The utilization of municipal solid waste (MSW) as a feedstock for torrefaction can address major issues traditionally associated with biomass supply logistics including limited harvest periods, large collection ranges, relatively low energy yield, and perhaps most importantly, high feedstock cost. One area of uncertainty with high-technical risk when considering torrefied MSW is the feedstock heterogeneity – specifically the mineral content (both water soluble, and water insoluble), which produce slagging and fouling in solid fuel boilers. We have developed the technology (the ThermShear process) to overcome this barrier by use a pretreatment method that will create a high value, uniform fuel through mineral removal. The investigation of this mineral removal process was the focus of the NSF project, in addition to evaluating other process requirements such as fuel heating value and product compaction.

During initial evaluation, the material had rather high mineral content as a whole sample (~15-20%). We showed that our ThermShear process enabled us to obtain two product fractions, one that comprises mostly of minerals, and the other that comprises mostly organic material that can be used as a clean solid fuel. This produced a relatively clean fuel (reducing the mineral content from 20% to less than 3-5%)  that can be used directly in coal boilers without causing operational issues.  I addition, it was shown that the process aids in reducing the formation of harmful pollutants such as SOx and some heavy metals, while eliminating the production of hydrochloric acid (HCl), PCDDs (dioxins), and PCDFs (furans) during the combustion of the solid fuel product. If implemented for power utilities, this could develop an entirely new high-volume industry and create many new jobs in areas in and around landfill operations. These are typically located in rural areas surrounding metropolitan areas, or between several cities where job creation is needed most. Simultaneously, the process significantly reduces the volume of material currently going to landfills (reduce by >75%) with minimal processing costs.

Through this project we have developed a viable technology to demonstrate our proposal to overcome the major barrier to utilization of MSW for power applications. This was achieved by developing and validating a pretreatment method (ThermShear) that will create a high value, uniform fuel through mineral removal.  The process and product were shown to comply with environmental regulations and with customers' needs.
